Line 51: Line 51:
{{Main|Davian behavior}}
{{Main|Davian behavior}}
â
Necrophilia is known to occur in animals, with a number of confirmed observations.<ref name="Guardian 2: Electric Boogaloo">{{cite news | url = http://education.guardian.co.uk/higher/research/improbable/story/0,,1437560,00.html | title = Randy rock doves join party with the dead | accessdate = 2007-06-17 | work = [[The Guardian]] | location=London | date=2005-03-14}}</ref> [[Kees Moeliker]] allegedly made one of these observations while he was sitting in his office at the [[Natuurmuseum Rotterdam]], when he heard the distinctive thud of a bird hitting the glass facade of the building. Upon inspection, he discovered a drake (male) [[mallard]] lying dead about two metres from the building. Next to the downed bird there was a second drake mallard standing close by. As Moeliker observed the couple, the living drake picked at the corpse of the dead one for a few minutes and then mounted the corpse and began having sex with it. The act of necrophilia lasted for about 75 minutes, in which time, according to Moeliker, the living drake took two short breaks before resuming with copulating behavior. Moeliker surmised that at the time of the collision with the window the two mallards were engaged in a common pattern in [[duck]] behavior which is called "[[rape]] flight". "When one died the other one just went for it and didn't get any negative feedback — well, didn't get any feedback," according to Moeliker.<ref name="Mallard Duck">{{cite journal | author=C.W. Moeliker| title=The first case of homosexual necrophilia in the Anas platyrhynchos (Aves:Anatidae)| journal=Deinsea - Annual of the Natural History Museum Rotterdam| year=2001| volume=8| pages=243â247}}</ref><ref name="MallardDuck">{{cite news | url=http://education.guardian.co.uk/higher/research/story/0,9865,1432991,00.html | title = Necrophilia among ducks ruffles research feathers|accessdate = 2007-06-17|publisher=Guardian Unlimited|author=Donald MacLeod | location=London | date=2005-03-08}}</ref> This is the first recorded case of necrophilia in the [[mallard duck]]- though not the only recorded case of [[homosexuality]] within the bird family.<ref name="NYTSqueak">{{cite news |first=Dinitia |last=Smith | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2004/02/07/arts/07GAY.html?scp=1&sq=Love%20that%20dare%20not%20squeak%20its%20name&st=cse |title=Love That Dare Not Squeak Its Name |publisher=New York Times |page=7 |date=2004-02-07}}</ref>
+
Necrophilia is known to occur in animals, with a number of confirmed observations.<ref name="Guardian 2: Electric Boogaloo">{{cite news | url = http://education.guardian.co.uk/higher/research/improbable/story/0,,1437560,00.html | title = Randy rock doves join party with the dead | accessdate = 2007-06-17 | work = [[The Guardian]] | location=London | date=2005-03-14}}</ref> [[Kees Moeliker]] allegedly made one of these observations while he was sitting in his office at the [[Natuurmuseum Rotterdam]], when he heard the distinctive thud of a bird hitting the glass facade of the building. Upon inspection, he discovered a drake (male) [[mallard]] lying dead about two meters from the building. Next to the downed bird there was a second drake mallard standing close by. As Moeliker observed the couple, the living drake picked at the corpse of the dead one for a few minutes and then mounted the corpse and began having sex with it. The act of necrophilia lasted for about 75 minutes, in which time, according to Moeliker, the living drake took two short breaks before resuming with copulating behavior. Moeliker surmised that at the time of the collision with the window the two mallards were engaged in a common pattern in [[duck]] behavior which is called "[[rape]] flight". "When one died the other one just went for it and didn't get any negative feedback — well, didn't get any feedback," according to Moeliker.<ref name="Mallard Duck">{{cite journal | author=C.W. Moeliker| title=The first case of homosexual necrophilia in the Anas platyrhynchos (Aves:Anatidae)| journal=Deinsea - Annual of the Natural History Museum Rotterdam| year=2001| volume=8| pages=243â247}}</ref><ref name="MallardDuck">{{cite news | url=http://education.guardian.co.uk/higher/research/story/0,9865,1432991,00.html | title = Necrophilia among ducks ruffles research feathers|accessdate = 2007-06-17|publisher=Guardian Unlimited|author=Donald MacLeod | location=London | date=2005-03-08}}</ref> This is the first recorded case of necrophilia in the [[mallard duck]]- though not the only recorded case of [[homosexuality]] within the bird family.<ref name="NYTSqueak">{{cite news |first=Dinitia |last=Smith | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2004/02/07/arts/07GAY.html?scp=1&sq=Love%20that%20dare%20not%20squeak%20its%20name&st=cse |title=Love That Dare Not Squeak Its Name |publisher=New York Times |page=7 |date=2004-02-07}}</ref>
â
The film ''The Cane Toads: an Unnatural History'' shows a male toad copulating with a female toad that has been run over by a car. He goes on to do this for eight hours.<ref>Lewis, 1989 S. Lewis, Cane Toads: an Unnatural History, Doubleday, New York (1989).</ref>
+
The film ''The Cane Toads: an Unnatural History'' shows a male toad copulating with a female toad who has been run over by a car. He goes on to do this for eight hours.<ref>Lewis, 1989 S. Lewis, Cane Toads: an Unnatural History, Doubleday, New York (1989).</ref>
In the case of a [[praying mantis]], necrophilia could be said to be part of their methods of [[reproduction]]. The larger female will sometimes decapitate or even eat her mate during copulation. However, this only happens in 5-31% of cases.<ref name="Feldman">{{Cite web|url=http://www.colostate.edu/Depts/Entomology/courses/en507/papers_1999/feldman.htm|title=The Praying Mantis|accessdate = 2007-06-17|author=Dan Feldman}}</ref>
In the case of a [[praying mantis]], necrophilia could be said to be part of their methods of [[reproduction]]. The larger female will sometimes decapitate or even eat her mate during copulation. However, this only happens in 5-31% of cases.<ref name="Feldman">{{Cite web|url=http://www.colostate.edu/Depts/Entomology/courses/en507/papers_1999/feldman.htm|title=The Praying Mantis|accessdate = 2007-06-17|author=Dan Feldman}}</ref>
